awd_titl_txt: Conference: Biophysical Society Annual Meeting - Multiscale Genome Organization Symposium
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support early career scientists attending the Multiscale Genome Organization subgroup symposium at the Biophysical Society Annual Meeting. Support will include sponsoring student trainees to attend and actively participate in the symposium. The trainees will help organize a career panel with scientists from diverse careers, with the goal of sharing information on various career paths and professional development strategies that promote retention in STEM-related fields.

The MGO subgroup brings together computational and experimental researchers with a focus on biophysical characterization of mechanisms underlying chromatin biology. The symposium will advance research and training in chromatin biology and catalyze cross-disciplinary collaborations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award was used to fund the attendance of five trainees to the 67th Annual meeting of the Biophysical Society in 2023, including the Multiscale Genome Organization Symposium held on “Subgroup Saturday” at the start of the meeting. The trainees enhanced their general knowledge base and professional network while at the meeting. In addition, they enhanced their professional development through publication of a meeting report of the MGO Symposium and organization of a Career Panel.

The career panel included a PI of an R1 ranked Academic Laboratory (Dr. Emma Morrison, Medical College of Wisconsin), a PI from a PUI (Dr. Diana Chu, San Francisco State University), and a scientist from Industry (Dr. Zhe Li Salie, Loxo Oncology). The awardees developed discussion questions for the panel which included the following:

Question set A (General questions for all panelists):

  1. Could you briefly describe the pros and cons of your job? What kind of person would be suitable for the job?
  2. What is your least favorite part of your current job and have you figured out a way to make it easier over time?
  3. What kind of job options did you have before, and what were the reasons you chose your current job? -- How to make better decisions in one's career?
  4. Was there any big decision that you made that you feel defined your career?
  5. Any difficulties that you faced and learned a lot after getting through them?
  6. Have you felt yourself changing your priorities (i.e., research versus mentorship versus life/family/friends) over the course of your career and did you feel like this was your choice?
  7. What is the timeline for application to job in your position?

 

Question set B (Panelist specific questions):

  1. For Emma – How did you separate yourself from your postdoctoral mentor? 
  2. For Zhe – Does industry generally prefer people just out of their PhDs?
  3. For Diana – What made you choose this type of academic path instead of a tenure track position at a R1 institute or an industry path? 
  4. For Emma – Submitting successful grant applications appears to be one of the main challenges for a PI in a R1 institution. Do you agree? What is your advice for someone who is dissuaded from pursuing a similar position due to this challenge despite being interested in academic research?
  5. For Zhe – Since most engineering and science PhDs never see industry roles, how can one tell if industry would suit them better?
  6. For Diana – What are some main challenges with conducting research and submitting successful grant applications in a primarily undergraduate institution?

 

Question Set C (Panelist specific questions):

  1. For Zhe – Do you often experience rigid productivity expectation in your companies? How do you facilitate autonomy, creativity and innovation in such an environment?
  2. For Emma – How did you decide it was time to go on the job market?
  3. For Diana – What are some keys to successful mentorship in your research group? Have you been successful in encouraging your students to pursue graduate school?
  4. For Zhe – Does your company promote opportunities for scientific innovation and/or publication for its employees?
  5. For Emma – What are some key challenges to forming inter-departmental or cross-campus collaborations? How about cross-institution collaborations? How have you overcome these?
  6. For Diana – Have you been able to form inter-institution collaborations with PIs in R1 institutions? What are some keys to forming such collaboration?

 

Question Set D (Panelist specific questions – if there is time):

  1. For Zhe – If after graduation, one decides to go into to industry, how does one sell themselves to people in the industry? 
  2. For Diana – How much do you teach per year versus how much time do you spend in lab?
  3. For Emma – How do you decide on a publishable unit? In other words, should one aim to write a large project as a big paper or try to distribute it into multiple smaller works?

The panel was held during the annual meeting. The awardees facilitated the discussion which was open to all conference participants and well attended.

 The awardees also generated a meeting report for the MGO Symposium. The symposium speakers included:

  • Job Dekker from University of Massachusetts Chan Medical School, Worcester, MA
  • Frank Alber from UCLA, Los Angeles, CA
  • Yaojun Zhang from Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD
  • Igor Sharakhov from Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, VA
  • Ranya Virk from Northwestern University
  • Shasha Chong from Caltech, Pasadena, CA
  • Devarajan Thirumalai from University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX

The awardees wrote the first draft of the meeting report which was edited by Drs. Musselman and Wereszczynski and run by the speakers for final approval. This was published in Biophysical Reviews(Akbari et al. 2023).

Akbari E, Park E-J, Singh AK, et al (2023) Multiscale genome organization symposium — annual biophysical society meeting 2023. Biophys Rev 15:313–315. https://doi.org/10.1007/s12551-023-01063-8
